Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were a jackrabbit hopping 
through the desert, you’d be glad to stumble— 
well, maybe not stumble— across a cactus: the succulent flesh 
of these plants is a water source for many desert animals. Native to the Americas and known 
for their spines and succulent stems, cacti of all shapes and sizes have evolved
to not just survive, but thrive, in some of the harshest desert climates 
on Earth. So how do they do it? A cactus’s spines are one
key to its survival— but not for the reason you might think. Take a look at the prickly pear. Its spines are highly modified leaves. A normal leaf’s large surface area would
be ill-suited to the desert, transpiring massive amounts 
of water under the baking sun. The dramatically reduced surface area
of the spines limits water loss. They also shade the cactus 
and reflect the sun’s rays, reducing the plant's core temperature
during the heat of the day. Then, at night, 
when air temperatures plummet, the spines act as an insulating layer, keeping the cactus from cooling 
down too much. These functions are just as important,
if not more, than defending against predators. From Cuba to Mexico, and as far south 
as Brazil and Peru, Melon cacti grow on limestone soils 
in seasonally dry tropical forests, where they're constantly exposed
to the beating sun. They rely on another adaptation
common to cacti: a thick skin, which is coated in a waxy substance
called a cuticle that limits water loss. Meanwhile, the stomata— tiny holes that allow the exchange
of gases that enable photosynthesis— remain firmly closed 
until night when they open. The lower temperatures at night 
mean the cactus loses less water from the stem when the stomata open. The bulk of the plant acts 
as a large barrel of water, storing it for times of need. But to survive the desert, 
a cactus can’t just limit water loss— it has to be prepared 
to take full advantage of the rare situations where water
is readily available. In North America’s Sonoran Desert, the towering Saguaro cactus can grow
up to 20 meters tall and live for up to 200 years. Woody tissue, like the kind found 
in tree trunks, give the Saguaro its height, but the Saguaro survives 
with way less water than most trees. Most of its roots are only 
a few inches deep. Just below the soil’s surface, 
they spread out laterally for meters and hold the plant in place. Even its single deepest root,
the taproot, extends less than one meter 
into the ground. After a rain, the lateral roots
respond in real time, rapidly growing and spreading. They produce ephemeral rain roots 
that quickly take up the available water. The water is then pulled
up into the plant body and stored in cells that contain mucilage, a gluey substance that clings 
to water molecules and stops them from evaporating 
if the plant’s tissue is ever damaged and exposed. As the soil dries after the rain, the small rain roots also start to dry 
and wither away, and the cactus awaits the next time
it can take advantage of a shower. Taken together, these features make cacti
well-equipped to survive their environments, from the driest desert
to... a tropical rainforest? The mistletoe cactus can live on the
branches of trees in the rainforest. Though there’s lots of water around,
not much of it reaches the cactus here, and there's nowhere for its roots to go. So even here, the cactus survives 
using adaptations that long ago helped its ancestors 
survive the desert.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What part of the world are cacti native to?
Options: A. The Americas, B. Africa, C. India, D. Europe, E. Australia
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a primary function of a cactus's spines? Options: A. To defend against predators, B. To store water, C. To limit water loss and shade the cactus, D. To absorb sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 2: Describe how a cactus's spines act as an insulating layer at night. Options: A. They allow the cactus to absorb more heat, B. They keep the cactus from cooling down too much, C. They help the cactus to photosynthesize more efficiently, D. They help the cactus to transpire more water Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having access to plenty of water? Options: A. They have deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. They have adaptations that help them conserve water, C. They have a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, D. They don't have to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the main reason why a cactus's spines are highly modified leaves? Options: A. To increase the surface area for photosynthesis, B. To reduce water loss and shade the cactus, C. To defend against predators, D. To absorb more sunlight Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do cacti store water in their stems? Options: A. By using mucilage to cling to water molecules, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By storing it in cells that contain a gluey substance, D. By having a large barrel of water that stores it for times of need Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of the ephemeral rain roots produced by a cactus after a rain? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To take up available water and store it in the plant body, D. To dry and wither away Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a key adaptation that allows a cactus to survive in the desert? Options: A. Its ability to photosynthesize more efficiently, B. Its ability to transpire more water, C. Its ability to limit water loss and take advantage of rare situations where water is readily available, D. Its ability to absorb more sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do cacti in North America's Sonoran Desert survive with limited water? Options: A. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By using woody tissue to give them height and store water, D. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of the mucilage in a cactus's cells? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To cling to water molecules and prevent them from evaporating, D. To store water Correct Option: C
Question 10: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having limited access to water? Options: A. By having adaptations that help them conserve water, B. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, C. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, D. By not having to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to inquire about the geographical origin of cacti, I can suggest a generated MCQ that might be tangentially related.

Generated MCQ 3 mentions cacti in tropical rainforests, and Generated MCQs 8 and 10 mention specific locations (North America's Sonoran Desert and tropical rainforests, respectively), but none of these questions directly address the native region of cacti.

That being said, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is remotely related to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Generated MCQ 8, which mentions a specific location (North America's Sonoran Desert). However, please note that this is a weak match, as the generated MCQ does not directly address the question of where cacti are native to.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8 (weak match)

A more accurate approach would be to generate a new MCQ that directly addresses the ground truth question, such as:

Generated MCQ: What region of the world are cacti originally from?
Options: A. The Americas, B. Africa, C. Asia, D. Europe, E. Australia

This would provide a more direct match to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were a jackrabbit hopping 
through the desert, you’d be glad to stumble— 
well, maybe not stumble— across a cactus: the succulent flesh 
of these plants is a water source for many desert animals. Native to the Americas and known 
for their spines and succulent stems, cacti of all shapes and sizes have evolved
to not just survive, but thrive, in some of the harshest desert climates 
on Earth. So how do they do it? A cactus’s spines are one
key to its survival— but not for the reason you might think. Take a look at the prickly pear. Its spines are highly modified leaves. A normal leaf’s large surface area would
be ill-suited to the desert, transpiring massive amounts 
of water under the baking sun. The dramatically reduced surface area
of the spines limits water loss. They also shade the cactus 
and reflect the sun’s rays, reducing the plant's core temperature
during the heat of the day. Then, at night, 
when air temperatures plummet, the spines act as an insulating layer, keeping the cactus from cooling 
down too much. These functions are just as important,
if not more, than defending against predators. From Cuba to Mexico, and as far south 
as Brazil and Peru, Melon cacti grow on limestone soils 
in seasonally dry tropical forests, where they're constantly exposed
to the beating sun. They rely on another adaptation
common to cacti: a thick skin, which is coated in a waxy substance
called a cuticle that limits water loss. Meanwhile, the stomata— tiny holes that allow the exchange
of gases that enable photosynthesis— remain firmly closed 
until night when they open. The lower temperatures at night 
mean the cactus loses less water from the stem when the stomata open. The bulk of the plant acts 
as a large barrel of water, storing it for times of need. But to survive the desert, 
a cactus can’t just limit water loss— it has to be prepared 
to take full advantage of the rare situations where water
is readily available. In North America’s Sonoran Desert, the towering Saguaro cactus can grow
up to 20 meters tall and live for up to 200 years. Woody tissue, like the kind found 
in tree trunks, give the Saguaro its height, but the Saguaro survives 
with way less water than most trees. Most of its roots are only 
a few inches deep. Just below the soil’s surface, 
they spread out laterally for meters and hold the plant in place. Even its single deepest root,
the taproot, extends less than one meter 
into the ground. After a rain, the lateral roots
respond in real time, rapidly growing and spreading. They produce ephemeral rain roots 
that quickly take up the available water. The water is then pulled
up into the plant body and stored in cells that contain mucilage, a gluey substance that clings 
to water molecules and stops them from evaporating 
if the plant’s tissue is ever damaged and exposed. As the soil dries after the rain, the small rain roots also start to dry 
and wither away, and the cactus awaits the next time
it can take advantage of a shower. Taken together, these features make cacti
well-equipped to survive their environments, from the driest desert
to... a tropical rainforest? The mistletoe cactus can live on the
branches of trees in the rainforest. Though there’s lots of water around,
not much of it reaches the cactus here, and there's nowhere for its roots to go. So even here, the cactus survives 
using adaptations that long ago helped its ancestors 
survive the desert.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What plant structure are the spines on a cactus a modification of?
Options: A. roots, B. hairs, C. leaves, D. flowers
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a primary function of a cactus's spines? Options: A. To defend against predators, B. To store water, C. To limit water loss and shade the cactus, D. To absorb sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 2: Describe how a cactus's spines act as an insulating layer at night. Options: A. They allow the cactus to absorb more heat, B. They keep the cactus from cooling down too much, C. They help the cactus to photosynthesize more efficiently, D. They help the cactus to transpire more water Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having access to plenty of water? Options: A. They have deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. They have adaptations that help them conserve water, C. They have a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, D. They don't have to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the main reason why a cactus's spines are highly modified leaves? Options: A. To increase the surface area for photosynthesis, B. To reduce water loss and shade the cactus, C. To defend against predators, D. To absorb more sunlight Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do cacti store water in their stems? Options: A. By using mucilage to cling to water molecules, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By storing it in cells that contain a gluey substance, D. By having a large barrel of water that stores it for times of need Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of the ephemeral rain roots produced by a cactus after a rain? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To take up available water and store it in the plant body, D. To dry and wither away Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a key adaptation that allows a cactus to survive in the desert? Options: A. Its ability to photosynthesize more efficiently, B. Its ability to transpire more water, C. Its ability to limit water loss and take advantage of rare situations where water is readily available, D. Its ability to absorb more sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do cacti in North America's Sonoran Desert survive with limited water? Options: A. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By using woody tissue to give them height and store water, D. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of the mucilage in a cactus's cells? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To cling to water molecules and prevent them from evaporating, D. To store water Correct Option: C
Question 10: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having limited access to water? Options: A. By having adaptations that help them conserve water, B. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, C. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, D. By not having to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What is the main reason why a cactus's spines are highly modified leaves?

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the plant structure that the spines on a cactus are a modification of. The correct option in Question 4, "To reduce water loss and shade the cactus," implies that the spines are modified leaves, which is the same answer as the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
If you were a jackrabbit hopping 
through the desert, you’d be glad to stumble— 
well, maybe not stumble— across a cactus: the succulent flesh 
of these plants is a water source for many desert animals. Native to the Americas and known 
for their spines and succulent stems, cacti of all shapes and sizes have evolved
to not just survive, but thrive, in some of the harshest desert climates 
on Earth. So how do they do it? A cactus’s spines are one
key to its survival— but not for the reason you might think. Take a look at the prickly pear. Its spines are highly modified leaves. A normal leaf’s large surface area would
be ill-suited to the desert, transpiring massive amounts 
of water under the baking sun. The dramatically reduced surface area
of the spines limits water loss. They also shade the cactus 
and reflect the sun’s rays, reducing the plant's core temperature
during the heat of the day. Then, at night, 
when air temperatures plummet, the spines act as an insulating layer, keeping the cactus from cooling 
down too much. These functions are just as important,
if not more, than defending against predators. From Cuba to Mexico, and as far south 
as Brazil and Peru, Melon cacti grow on limestone soils 
in seasonally dry tropical forests, where they're constantly exposed
to the beating sun. They rely on another adaptation
common to cacti: a thick skin, which is coated in a waxy substance
called a cuticle that limits water loss. Meanwhile, the stomata— tiny holes that allow the exchange
of gases that enable photosynthesis— remain firmly closed 
until night when they open. The lower temperatures at night 
mean the cactus loses less water from the stem when the stomata open. The bulk of the plant acts 
as a large barrel of water, storing it for times of need. But to survive the desert, 
a cactus can’t just limit water loss— it has to be prepared 
to take full advantage of the rare situations where water
is readily available. In North America’s Sonoran Desert, the towering Saguaro cactus can grow
up to 20 meters tall and live for up to 200 years. Woody tissue, like the kind found 
in tree trunks, give the Saguaro its height, but the Saguaro survives 
with way less water than most trees. Most of its roots are only 
a few inches deep. Just below the soil’s surface, 
they spread out laterally for meters and hold the plant in place. Even its single deepest root,
the taproot, extends less than one meter 
into the ground. After a rain, the lateral roots
respond in real time, rapidly growing and spreading. They produce ephemeral rain roots 
that quickly take up the available water. The water is then pulled
up into the plant body and stored in cells that contain mucilage, a gluey substance that clings 
to water molecules and stops them from evaporating 
if the plant’s tissue is ever damaged and exposed. As the soil dries after the rain, the small rain roots also start to dry 
and wither away, and the cactus awaits the next time
it can take advantage of a shower. Taken together, these features make cacti
well-equipped to survive their environments, from the driest desert
to... a tropical rainforest? The mistletoe cactus can live on the
branches of trees in the rainforest. Though there’s lots of water around,
not much of it reaches the cactus here, and there's nowhere for its roots to go. So even here, the cactus survives 
using adaptations that long ago helped its ancestors 
survive the desert.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the gooey substance inside a cactus that helps it retain water?
Options: A. Starch, B. Mucilage, C. Epidermis, D. Salt
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
If you were a jackrabbit hopping 
through the desert, you’d be glad to stumble— 
well, maybe not stumble— across a cactus: the succulent flesh 
of these plants is a water source for many desert animals. Native to the Americas and known 
for their spines and succulent stems, cacti of all shapes and sizes have evolved
to not just survive, but thrive, in some of the harshest desert climates 
on Earth. So how do they do it? A cactus’s spines are one

be ill-suited to the desert, transpiring massive amounts 
of water under the baking sun. The dramatically reduced surface area

during the heat of the day. Then, at night,

down too much. These functions are just as important,

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were a jackrabbit hopping 
through the desert, you’d be glad to stumble— 
well, maybe not stumble— across a cactus: the succulent flesh 
of these plants is a water source for many desert animals. Native to the Americas and known 
for their spines and succulent stems, cacti of all shapes and sizes have evolved
to not just survive, but thrive, in some of the harshest desert climates 
on Earth. So how do they do it? A cactus’s spines are one
key to its survival— but not for the reason you might think. Take a look at the prickly pear. Its spines are highly modified leaves. A normal leaf’s large surface area would
be ill-suited to the desert, transpiring massive amounts 
of water under the baking sun. The dramatically reduced surface area
of the spines limits water loss. They also shade the cactus 
and reflect the sun’s rays, reducing the plant's core temperature
during the heat of the day. Then, at night, 
when air temperatures plummet, the spines act as an insulating layer, keeping the cactus from cooling 
down too much. These functions are just as important,
if not more, than defending against predators. From Cuba to Mexico, and as far south 
as Brazil and Peru, Melon cacti grow on limestone soils 
in seasonally dry tropical forests, where they're constantly exposed
to the beating sun. They rely on another adaptation
common to cacti: a thick skin, which is coated in a waxy substance
called a cuticle that limits water loss. Meanwhile, the stomata— tiny holes that allow the exchange
of gases that enable photosynthesis— remain firmly closed 
until night when they open. The lower temperatures at night 
mean the cactus loses less water from the stem when the stomata open. The bulk of the plant acts 
as a large barrel of water, storing it for times of need. But to survive the desert, 
a cactus can’t just limit water loss— it has to be prepared 
to take full advantage of the rare situations where water
is readily available. In North America’s Sonoran Desert, the towering Saguaro cactus can grow
up to 20 meters tall and live for up to 200 years. Woody tissue, like the kind found 
in tree trunks, give the Saguaro its height, but the Saguaro survives 
with way less water than most trees. Most of its roots are only 
a few inches deep. Just below the soil’s surface, 
they spread out laterally for meters and hold the plant in place. Even its single deepest root,
the taproot, extends less than one meter 
into the ground. After a rain, the lateral roots
respond in real time, rapidly growing and spreading. They produce ephemeral rain roots 
that quickly take up the available water. The water is then pulled
up into the plant body and stored in cells that contain mucilage, a gluey substance that clings 
to water molecules and stops them from evaporating 
if the plant’s tissue is ever damaged and exposed. As the soil dries after the rain, the small rain roots also start to dry 
and wither away, and the cactus awaits the next time
it can take advantage of a shower. Taken together, these features make cacti
well-equipped to survive their environments, from the driest desert
to... a tropical rainforest? The mistletoe cactus can live on the
branches of trees in the rainforest. Though there’s lots of water around,
not much of it reaches the cactus here, and there's nowhere for its roots to go. So even here, the cactus survives 
using adaptations that long ago helped its ancestors 
survive the desert.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of roots do cacti produce in response to precipitation?
Options: A. Spine roots, B. Rain roots, C. Tap roots, D. Aerial roots
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a primary function of a cactus's spines? Options: A. To defend against predators, B. To store water, C. To limit water loss and shade the cactus, D. To absorb sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 2: Describe how a cactus's spines act as an insulating layer at night. Options: A. They allow the cactus to absorb more heat, B. They keep the cactus from cooling down too much, C. They help the cactus to photosynthesize more efficiently, D. They help the cactus to transpire more water Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having access to plenty of water? Options: A. They have deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. They have adaptations that help them conserve water, C. They have a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, D. They don't have to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the main reason why a cactus's spines are highly modified leaves? Options: A. To increase the surface area for photosynthesis, B. To reduce water loss and shade the cactus, C. To defend against predators, D. To absorb more sunlight Correct Option: B
Question 5: How do cacti store water in their stems? Options: A. By using mucilage to cling to water molecules, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By storing it in cells that contain a gluey substance, D. By having a large barrel of water that stores it for times of need Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of the ephemeral rain roots produced by a cactus after a rain? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To take up available water and store it in the plant body, D. To dry and wither away Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a key adaptation that allows a cactus to survive in the desert? Options: A. Its ability to photosynthesize more efficiently, B. Its ability to transpire more water, C. Its ability to limit water loss and take advantage of rare situations where water is readily available, D. Its ability to absorb more sunlight Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do cacti in North America's Sonoran Desert survive with limited water? Options: A. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, B. By having a thick skin that limits water loss, C. By using woody tissue to give them height and store water, D. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of the mucilage in a cactus's cells? Options: A. To absorb more sunlight, B. To defend against predators, C. To cling to water molecules and prevent them from evaporating, D. To store water Correct Option: C
Question 10: How do cacti in tropical rainforests survive despite having limited access to water? Options: A. By having adaptations that help them conserve water, B. By having a different type of root system that allows them to absorb more water, C. By having deep roots that can reach water deep in the soil, D. By not having to conserve water because it's always available Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is the purpose of the ephemeral rain roots produced by a cactus after a rain? 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the type of roots cacti produce in response to precipitation. The correct option in Question 6, "To take up available water and store it in the plant body," is also related to the concept of rain roots, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were buying a car in 1899, you would’ve had three major
options to choose from. You could buy a steam-powered car. Typically relying on gas-powered boilers, 
these could drive as far as you wanted— provided you also wanted to lug
around extra water to refuel and didn’t mind waiting 30 minutes
for your engine to heat up. Alternatively, you could buy
a car powered by gasoline. However, the internal combustion engines
in these models required dangerous hand-cranking to start and emitted loud noises
and foul-smelling exhaust while driving. So your best bet was probably
option number three: a battery-powered electric vehicle. These cars were quick to start,
clean and quiet to run, and if you lived somewhere with access 
to electricity, easy to refuel overnight. If this seems like an easy choice,
you're not alone. By the end of the 19th century, 
nearly 40% of American cars were electric. In cities with early electric systems, battery-powered cars were 
a popular and reliable alternative to their occasionally explosive 
competitors. But electric vehicles had one
major problem— batteries. Early car batteries were expensive
and inefficient. Many inventors, including Thomas Edison, tried to build batteries 
that stored more electricity. Others even built exchange stations 
in urban areas to swap out dead batteries for charged ones. But these measures weren’t enough to allow
electric vehicles to make long trips. And at over twice the price 
of a gas-powered car, many couldn’t afford these luxury items. At the same time, oil discoveries
lowered the price of gasoline, and new advances made internal combustion
engines more appealing. Electric starters removed the need
for hand-cranking, mufflers made engines quieter and 
rubber engine mounts reduced vibration. In 1908, Ford released the Model T; a cheap, high-quality gas-powered car 
that captured the public imagination. By 1915, the percentage of electric cars
on the road had plummeted. For the next 55 years, internal combustion
engines ruled the roads. Aside from some special-purpose vehicles,
electric cars were nowhere to be found. However, in the 1970s, 
the tide began to turn. US concerns about oil availability renewed
interest in alternative energy sources. And studies in the 1980s linking 
car emissions with smog in cities like Los Angeles encouraged governments 
and environmental organizations to reconsider electric vehicles. At this point, car companies had spent
decades investing in internal combustion engines 
without devoting any resources to solving the century-old 
battery problem. But other companies were developing
increasingly efficient batteries to power a new wave 
of portable electronics. By the 1990s, energy dense nickel metal
hydride batteries were on the market, soon followed by lithium-ion batteries. Alongside regulatory mandates 
by California to reduce smog, these innovations sparked a small wave
of new electric vehicles, including hybrid cars. Hybrids aren’t true electric vehicles; their nickel metal hydride batteries are only used to optimize 
the efficiency of gas-burning engines. But in 2008, Tesla Motors went further, grabbing the attention of consumers, 
automakers, and regulators with its lithium-ion-powered Roadster. This purely electric vehicle could travel 
more than 320 kilometers on a single charge, almost doubling the previous record. Since then, electric vehicles have 
vastly improved in cost, performance, efficiency, and availability. They can accelerate much faster
than gas-powered sports cars, and while some models still
have a high upfront cost, they reliably save their drivers money
in the long run. As governments around the world focus 
on slowing climate change, electric vehicles are now expected 
to replace gas-powered ones altogether. In Norway, 75% of car sales in 2020 
were plug-in electric vehicles. And policies such as California’s
Zero Emission Vehicle mandate and Europe’s aggressive 
CO2 emission standards have dramatically slowed investments 
in gas-powered vehicles worldwide. Soon, electric cars will reclaim 
their place on the road, putting gasoline in our rearview.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was a major flaw of early electric vehicles?
Options: A. They were noisy and foul-smelling, B. They were expensive, C. The engine took 30 minutes to heat up, D. They required hand-cranking
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of car was popular in cities with early electric systems at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. Gasoline-powered car, B. Steam-powered car, C. Battery-powered electric vehicle, D. Hybrid car Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main problem with electric vehicles at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. They were too expensive, B. They were too inefficient, C. They had a major problem with batteries, D. They were too slow Correct Option: C
Question 3: In 1908, Ford released a car that captured the public imagination and had a significant impact on the market. What type of car was it? Options: A. Electric car, B. Gasoline-powered car, C. Hybrid car, D. Steam-powered car Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the decline of electric cars in the early 20th century? Options: A. The rise of hybrid cars, B. The decline of oil prices, C. The development of more efficient batteries, D. The lack of investment in electric vehicles Correct Option: D
Question 5: In the 1970s, what event renewed interest in alternative energy sources and electric vehicles? Options: A. The discovery of new oil reserves, B. The development of more efficient batteries, C. US concerns about oil availability, D. The rise of hybrid cars Correct Option: C
Question 6: What type of battery was developed in the 1980s and sparked a small wave of new electric vehicles? Options: A. Nickel metal hydride battery, B. Lithium-ion battery, C. Lead-acid battery, D. Mercury battery Correct Option: A
Question 7: In 2008, which company released a lithium-ion-powered electric vehicle that could travel more than 320 kilometers on a single charge? Options: A. Tesla Motors, B. General Motors, C. Ford, D. Toyota Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is expected to replace gas-powered vehicles altogether in the future? Options: A. Hybrid cars, B. Electric vehicles, C. Steam-powered cars, D. Diesel cars Correct Option: B
Question 9: In Norway, what percentage of car sales in 2020 were plug-in electric vehicles? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 10: What policy has dramatically slowed investments in gas-powered vehicles worldwide? Options: A. California's Zero Emission Vehicle mandate, B. Europe's aggressive CO2 emission standards, C. Norway's electric vehicle tax credit, D. The US's fuel efficiency standards Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the wording of the question is different, the intent and content of Question 2 are similar to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions focus on the major flaw or problem of early electric vehicles. The correct option for Question 2, "They had a major problem with batteries," is related to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "They were expensive," as the transcript explains that early car batteries were expensive and inefficient.

However, it's worth noting that Question 2 is not an exact match, as the options and wording are not identical. Nevertheless, among the provided generated MCQs, Question 2 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3

**Transcript**:
If you were buying a car in 1899, you would’ve had three major
options to choose from. You could buy a steam-powered car. Typically relying on gas-powered boilers, 
these could drive as far as you wanted— provided you also wanted to lug
around extra water to refuel and didn’t mind waiting 30 minutes
for your engine to heat up. Alternatively, you could buy
a car powered by gasoline. However, the internal combustion engines
in these models required dangerous hand-cranking to start and emitted loud noises
and foul-smelling exhaust while driving. So your best bet was probably
option number three: a battery-powered electric vehicle. These cars were quick to start,
clean and quiet to run, and if you lived somewhere with access 
to electricity, easy to refuel overnight. If this seems like an easy choice,
you're not alone. By the end of the 19th century, 
nearly 40% of American cars were electric. In cities with early electric systems, battery-powered cars were 
a popular and reliable alternative to their occasionally explosive 
competitors. But electric vehicles had one
major problem— batteries. Early car batteries were expensive

Zero Emission Vehicle mandate and Europe’s aggressive 
CO2 emission standards have dramatically slowed investments

their place on the road, putting gasoline in our rearview.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What led to renewed interest in electric cars in the 1970s and 1980s?
Options: A. Availability of cheaper batteries, B. A government ban on gas burning engines, C. Movies featuring futuristic electric cars, D. Concerns about oil shortages and air pollution
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were buying a car in 1899, you would’ve had three major
options to choose from. You could buy a steam-powered car. Typically relying on gas-powered boilers, 
these could drive as far as you wanted— provided you also wanted to lug
around extra water to refuel and didn’t mind waiting 30 minutes
for your engine to heat up. Alternatively, you could buy
a car powered by gasoline. However, the internal combustion engines
in these models required dangerous hand-cranking to start and emitted loud noises
and foul-smelling exhaust while driving. So your best bet was probably
option number three: a battery-powered electric vehicle. These cars were quick to start,
clean and quiet to run, and if you lived somewhere with access 
to electricity, easy to refuel overnight. If this seems like an easy choice,
you're not alone. By the end of the 19th century, 
nearly 40% of American cars were electric. In cities with early electric systems, battery-powered cars were 
a popular and reliable alternative to their occasionally explosive 
competitors. But electric vehicles had one
major problem— batteries. Early car batteries were expensive
and inefficient. Many inventors, including Thomas Edison, tried to build batteries 
that stored more electricity. Others even built exchange stations 
in urban areas to swap out dead batteries for charged ones. But these measures weren’t enough to allow
electric vehicles to make long trips. And at over twice the price 
of a gas-powered car, many couldn’t afford these luxury items. At the same time, oil discoveries
lowered the price of gasoline, and new advances made internal combustion
engines more appealing. Electric starters removed the need
for hand-cranking, mufflers made engines quieter and

that captured the public imagination. By 1915, the percentage of electric cars
on the road had plummeted. For the next 55 years, internal combustion
engines ruled the roads. Aside from some special-purpose vehicles,
electric cars were nowhere to be found. However, in the 1970s, 
the tide began to turn. US concerns about oil availability renewed
interest in alternative energy sources. And studies in the 1980s linking 
car emissions with smog in cities like Los Angeles encouraged governments 
and environmental organizations to reconsider electric vehicles. At this point, car companies had spent
decades investing in internal combustion engines 
without devoting any resources to solving the century-old 
battery problem. But other companies were developing
increasingly efficient batteries to power a new wave 
of portable electronics. By the 1990s, energy dense nickel metal
hydride batteries were on the market, soon followed by lithium-ion batteries. Alongside regulatory mandates 
by California to reduce smog, these innovations sparked a small wave
of new electric vehicles, including hybrid cars. Hybrids aren’t true electric vehicles; their nickel metal hydride batteries are only used to optimize 
the efficiency of gas-burning engines. But in 2008, Tesla Motors went further, grabbing the attention of consumers, 
automakers, and regulators with its lithium-ion-powered Roadster. This purely electric vehicle could travel 
more than 320 kilometers on a single charge, almost doubling the previous record. Since then, electric vehicles have 
vastly improved in cost, performance, efficiency, and availability. They can accelerate much faster
than gas-powered sports cars, and while some models still
have a high upfront cost, they reliably save their drivers money
in the long run. As governments around the world focus 
on slowing climate change, electric vehicles are now expected 
to replace gas-powered ones altogether. In Norway, 75% of car sales in 2020 
were plug-in electric vehicles. And policies such as California’s
Zero Emission Vehicle mandate and Europe’s aggressive 
CO2 emission standards have dramatically slowed investments 
in gas-powered vehicles worldwide. Soon, electric cars will reclaim 
their place on the road, putting gasoline in our rearview.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What made it possible for Tesla’s Roadster to travel more than 320 km on a single charge?
Options: A. A nickel metal hydride battery, B. An electric starter, C. A lithium-ion battery, D. A hybrid electric and gas-powered engine
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of car was popular in cities with early electric systems at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. Gasoline-powered car, B. Steam-powered car, C. Battery-powered electric vehicle, D. Hybrid car Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main problem with electric vehicles at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. They were too expensive, B. They were too inefficient, C. They had a major problem with batteries, D. They were too slow Correct Option: C
Question 3: In 1908, Ford released a car that captured the public imagination and had a significant impact on the market. What type of car was it? Options: A. Electric car, B. Gasoline-powered car, C. Hybrid car, D. Steam-powered car Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the decline of electric cars in the early 20th century? Options: A. The rise of hybrid cars, B. The decline of oil prices, C. The development of more efficient batteries, D. The lack of investment in electric vehicles Correct Option: D
Question 5: In the 1970s, what event renewed interest in alternative energy sources and electric vehicles? Options: A. The discovery of new oil reserves, B. The development of more efficient batteries, C. US concerns about oil availability, D. The rise of hybrid cars Correct Option: C
Question 6: What type of battery was developed in the 1980s and sparked a small wave of new electric vehicles? Options: A. Nickel metal hydride battery, B. Lithium-ion battery, C. Lead-acid battery, D. Mercury battery Correct Option: A
Question 7: In 2008, which company released a lithium-ion-powered electric vehicle that could travel more than 320 kilometers on a single charge? Options: A. Tesla Motors, B. General Motors, C. Ford, D. Toyota Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is expected to replace gas-powered vehicles altogether in the future? Options: A. Hybrid cars, B. Electric vehicles, C. Steam-powered cars, D. Diesel cars Correct Option: B
Question 9: In Norway, what percentage of car sales in 2020 were plug-in electric vehicles? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 10: What policy has dramatically slowed investments in gas-powered vehicles worldwide? Options: A. California's Zero Emission Vehicle mandate, B. Europe's aggressive CO2 emission standards, C. Norway's electric vehicle tax credit, D. The US's fuel efficiency standards Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the key factor that enabled Tesla's Roadster to travel a significant distance on a single charge. Both questions focus on the type of battery used in the vehicle, and the correct option in both cases is related to the lithium-ion battery. 

Although the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the factor that enabled the Roadster to travel more than 320 km, and Question 7 is more focused on identifying the company that released the vehicle, the key information being tested is the same: the importance of the lithium-ion battery in achieving this milestone. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were buying a car in 1899, you would’ve had three major
options to choose from. You could buy a steam-powered car. Typically relying on gas-powered boilers, 
these could drive as far as you wanted— provided you also wanted to lug
around extra water to refuel and didn’t mind waiting 30 minutes
for your engine to heat up. Alternatively, you could buy
a car powered by gasoline. However, the internal combustion engines
in these models required dangerous hand-cranking to start and emitted loud noises
and foul-smelling exhaust while driving. So your best bet was probably
option number three: a battery-powered electric vehicle. These cars were quick to start,
clean and quiet to run, and if you lived somewhere with access 
to electricity, easy to refuel overnight. If this seems like an easy choice,
you're not alone. By the end of the 19th century, 
nearly 40% of American cars were electric. In cities with early electric systems, battery-powered cars were 
a popular and reliable alternative to their occasionally explosive 
competitors. But electric vehicles had one
major problem— batteries. Early car batteries were expensive
and inefficient. Many inventors, including Thomas Edison, tried to build batteries 
that stored more electricity. Others even built exchange stations 
in urban areas to swap out dead batteries for charged ones. But these measures weren’t enough to allow
electric vehicles to make long trips. And at over twice the price 
of a gas-powered car, many couldn’t afford these luxury items. At the same time, oil discoveries
lowered the price of gasoline, and new advances made internal combustion
engines more appealing. Electric starters removed the need
for hand-cranking, mufflers made engines quieter and 
rubber engine mounts reduced vibration. In 1908, Ford released the Model T; a cheap, high-quality gas-powered car 
that captured the public imagination. By 1915, the percentage of electric cars
on the road had plummeted. For the next 55 years, internal combustion
engines ruled the roads. Aside from some special-purpose vehicles,
electric cars were nowhere to be found. However, in the 1970s, 
the tide began to turn. US concerns about oil availability renewed
interest in alternative energy sources. And studies in the 1980s linking 
car emissions with smog in cities like Los Angeles encouraged governments 
and environmental organizations to reconsider electric vehicles. At this point, car companies had spent
decades investing in internal combustion engines 
without devoting any resources to solving the century-old 
battery problem. But other companies were developing
increasingly efficient batteries to power a new wave 
of portable electronics. By the 1990s, energy dense nickel metal
hydride batteries were on the market, soon followed by lithium-ion batteries. Alongside regulatory mandates 
by California to reduce smog, these innovations sparked a small wave
of new electric vehicles, including hybrid cars. Hybrids aren’t true electric vehicles; their nickel metal hydride batteries are only used to optimize 
the efficiency of gas-burning engines. But in 2008, Tesla Motors went further, grabbing the attention of consumers, 
automakers, and regulators with its lithium-ion-powered Roadster. This purely electric vehicle could travel 
more than 320 kilometers on a single charge, almost doubling the previous record. Since then, electric vehicles have 
vastly improved in cost, performance, efficiency, and availability. They can accelerate much faster
than gas-powered sports cars, and while some models still
have a high upfront cost, they reliably save their drivers money
in the long run. As governments around the world focus 
on slowing climate change, electric vehicles are now expected 
to replace gas-powered ones altogether. In Norway, 75% of car sales in 2020 
were plug-in electric vehicles. And policies such as California’s
Zero Emission Vehicle mandate and Europe’s aggressive 
CO2 emission standards have dramatically slowed investments 
in gas-powered vehicles worldwide. Soon, electric cars will reclaim 
their place on the road, putting gasoline in our rearview.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Norway, ___ percent of car sales in 2020 were plug-in electric vehicles.
Options: A. 82, B. 100, C. 75, D. 61
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of car was popular in cities with early electric systems at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. Gasoline-powered car, B. Steam-powered car, C. Battery-powered electric vehicle, D. Hybrid car Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the main problem with electric vehicles at the end of the 19th century? Options: A. They were too expensive, B. They were too inefficient, C. They had a major problem with batteries, D. They were too slow Correct Option: C
Question 3: In 1908, Ford released a car that captured the public imagination and had a significant impact on the market. What type of car was it? Options: A. Electric car, B. Gasoline-powered car, C. Hybrid car, D. Steam-powered car Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the main reason for the decline of electric cars in the early 20th century? Options: A. The rise of hybrid cars, B. The decline of oil prices, C. The development of more efficient batteries, D. The lack of investment in electric vehicles Correct Option: D
Question 5: In the 1970s, what event renewed interest in alternative energy sources and electric vehicles? Options: A. The discovery of new oil reserves, B. The development of more efficient batteries, C. US concerns about oil availability, D. The rise of hybrid cars Correct Option: C
Question 6: What type of battery was developed in the 1980s and sparked a small wave of new electric vehicles? Options: A. Nickel metal hydride battery, B. Lithium-ion battery, C. Lead-acid battery, D. Mercury battery Correct Option: A
Question 7: In 2008, which company released a lithium-ion-powered electric vehicle that could travel more than 320 kilometers on a single charge? Options: A. Tesla Motors, B. General Motors, C. Ford, D. Toyota Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is expected to replace gas-powered vehicles altogether in the future? Options: A. Hybrid cars, B. Electric vehicles, C. Steam-powered cars, D. Diesel cars Correct Option: B

Question 10: What policy has dramatically slowed investments in gas-powered vehicles worldwide? Options: A. California's Zero Emission Vehicle mandate, B. Europe's aggressive CO2 emission standards, C. Norway's electric vehicle tax credit, D. The US's fuel efficiency standards Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

**Question 9: In Norway, what percentage of car sales in 2020 were plug-in electric vehicles? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 90% Correct Option: C**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mohammadpur has always had 
a unique relationship with the weather. Located at the mouth of the Bay of Bengal, this coastal village was built 
on top of the Meghna River delta. Deltas are a kind of landmass formed 
when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where that river meets 
a larger body of water. River deltas are incredibly fertile
ecosystems capable of supporting abundant agriculture
and marine life. However, their borders gradually change
as rivers bring more sediment in and storms wash sediment away. The residents of Mohammadpur are well
accustomed to managing the ebbs and flows of this ever-shifting
landscape. But lately, an abundance of intense
cyclones have caused frequent flooding that impedes farming and fishing. These floods also erode the coastline, allowing later storms to wipe
away land altogether. Since 2000, the Meghna River has overtaken
the coastline by 2.5 kilometers, forcing many villagers to move inland
or to nearby cities. Mohammadpur isn’t the only place 
where erratic weather is impacting people’s mobility. Repeated typhoons in the Philippines have 
displaced thousands from their homes. In Fiji, the government is already moving
many coastal villages inland to get ahead of predicted land loss. And in the United States, melting permafrost is causing chunks
of the Alaskan coastline to erode. In some ways, this is nothing new. Humanity has always adapted
to changing weather and moved to regions that best support
cultural lifestyles and livelihoods. However, scientists agree 
that this rise in extreme weather is a by-product of Earth’s 
rapidly changing climate. Global warming increases the frequency and
intensity of storms, flooding and drought, while also melting polar ice caps 
and raising sea levels. These factors are changing the environment
much faster than they have in the past. Even for communities with the resources 
to take action, the variable pace and nature of these
changes makes them difficult to adapt to. And the vulnerable populations most
impacted by climate change are often those least responsible. Many facing climate mobility live 
in farming and fishing communities in countries that generate dramatically 
fewer emissions than their larger counterparts. Bangladesh is one such country. The nation has a unique combination
of low-lying geography and heavily populated coastal regions. Most of these vulnerable coastal families,
like those in Mohammadpur, don’t want to abandon 
their homes and livelihoods. And for others, leaving Bangladesh
isn’t financially practical. So to stay with their communities, many have moved a few meters inland and built more resilient homes
on higher ground or elevated stilts. Others have tried to buy land on newly
emerging islands in the delta, while some have sent family members
to find work in nearby cities. A handful of individuals might even cross
international borders, if they have family, friends, or work 
connections on the other side. But many of the residents who’ve left
are eager to return home. Unfortunately, it's unclear when
weather extremes will die down, and the government has repeatedly delayed
projects to build concrete embankments that would prevent further erosion. In other parts of the world, people couldn’t move inland 
even if they wanted to. The low-lying Pacific Island nations 
of Kiribati and Tuvalu are only 811 square kilometers
and 26 square kilometers, respectively; so migration would mean moving 
to a different country altogether. Instead, their governments and citizens
have united in physically, legally, and politically 
fortifying their countries. Island residents are planting
coastal mangrove forests, and building up low-lying areas of land
with dredged sand to shield themselves against storms 
and rising sea levels. And the islands’ governments have
repeatedly lobbied on the global stage for countries with the highest emissions 
to reduce pollution and take responsibility 
for climate change. The challenges facing
each coastal community are unique, and the diversity of the people's
experiences can make climate mobility a difficult phenomenon 
to measure and define. But as new communities are endangered
by extreme weather, it’s more important than ever
to listen to those on the front lines of this crisis.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Changes in the Bangladesh delta are:
Options: A. Natural to its ecosystem , B. Exacerbated due to climatic changes, C. Influenced by infrastructure, such as embankments, dams and barrages  , D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of landmass is formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where the river meets a larger body of water? Options: A. Mountain range, B. Island, C. Delta, D. Peninsula Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main reason for the frequent flooding in Mohammadpur? Options: A. Heavy rainfall, B. Intense cyclones, C. Erosion of the coastline, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 3: In what year did the Meghna River overtake the coastline by 2.5 kilometers, forcing many villagers to move inland or to nearby cities? Options: A. 2000, B. 2010, C. 2020, D. 2050 Correct Option: A
Question 4: Which of the following is NOT a way that the residents of Mohammadpur have adapted to the changing weather? Options: A. Building more resilient homes on higher ground, B. Sending family members to find work in nearby cities, C. Abandoning their homes and livelihoods, D. Moving to a different country Correct Option: C
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the main cause of the rise in extreme weather? Options: A. Human activity, B. Natural disasters, C. Global warming, D. Climate change Correct Option: D
Question 6: Which of the following countries is not responsible for a significant amount of greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. United States, B. China, C. Bangladesh, D. Bangladesh Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the name of the Pacific Island nation with a land area of 26 square kilometers? Options: A. Kiribati, B. Tuvalu, C. Fiji, D. Solomon Islands Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one way that the residents of Kiribati and Tuvalu are adapting to the rising sea levels? Options: A. Building concrete embankments, B. Planting coastal mangrove forests, C. Moving to a different country, D. Lobbying for countries with high emissions to reduce pollution Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main challenge facing coastal communities in terms of measuring and defining climate mobility? Options: A. The lack of data, B. The diversity of experiences, C. The complexity of the issue, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the importance of listening to those on the front lines of the climate crisis? Options: A. To understand the impact of climate change, B. To develop solutions to the problem, C. To raise awareness about the issue, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, its content and options are the most similar. Question 2 asks about the main reason for the frequent flooding in Mohammadpur, which is related to the changes in the Bangladesh delta. The correct option for Question 2 is "D. All of the above", which includes intense cyclones, erosion of the coastline, and heavy rainfall (implied). This is similar to the ground truth MCQ, which states that changes in the Bangladesh delta are natural to its ecosystem, exacerbated due to climatic changes, and influenced by infrastructure.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs seem to focus more on specific details from the transcript, whereas the ground truth MCQ takes a more holistic approach to understanding the changes in the Bangladesh delta.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

to measure and define. But as new communities are endangered

to listen to those on the front lines of this crisis.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mohammadpur has always had 
a unique relationship with the weather. Located at the mouth of the Bay of Bengal, this coastal village was built 
on top of the Meghna River delta. Deltas are a kind of landmass formed 
when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where that river meets 
a larger body of water. River deltas are incredibly fertile
ecosystems capable of supporting abundant agriculture
and marine life. However, their borders gradually change
as rivers bring more sediment in and storms wash sediment away. The residents of Mohammadpur are well

landscape. But lately, an abundance of intense

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which country’s government is pro-actively moving coastal villages inland:
Options: A. Fiji, B. Tuvalu, C. Philippines, D. Kiribati
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of landmass is formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where the river meets a larger body of water? Options: A. Mountain range, B. Island, C. Delta, D. Peninsula Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main reason for the frequent flooding in Mohammadpur? Options: A. Heavy rainfall, B. Intense cyclones, C. Erosion of the coastline, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Sending family members to find work in nearby cities, C. Abandoning their homes and livelihoods, D. Moving to a different country Correct Option: C

Question 6: Which of the following countries is not responsible for a significant amount of greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. United States, B. China, C. Bangladesh, D. Bangladesh Correct Option: D

Planting coastal mangrove forests, C. Moving to a different country, D. Lobbying for countries with high emissions to reduce pollution Correct Option: B

To develop solutions to the problem, C. To raise awareness about the issue, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mohammadpur has always had 
a unique relationship with the weather. Located at the mouth of the Bay of Bengal, this coastal village was built 
on top of the Meghna River delta. Deltas are a kind of landmass formed 
when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where that river meets 
a larger body of water. River deltas are incredibly fertile
ecosystems capable of supporting abundant agriculture
and marine life. However, their borders gradually change
as rivers bring more sediment in and storms wash sediment away. The residents of Mohammadpur are well
accustomed to managing the ebbs and flows of this ever-shifting
landscape. But lately, an abundance of intense
cyclones have caused frequent flooding that impedes farming and fishing. These floods also erode the coastline, allowing later storms to wipe
away land altogether. Since 2000, the Meghna River has overtaken
the coastline by 2.5 kilometers, forcing many villagers to move inland
or to nearby cities. Mohammadpur isn’t the only place 
where erratic weather is impacting people’s mobility. Repeated typhoons in the Philippines have 
displaced thousands from their homes. In Fiji, the government is already moving
many coastal villages inland to get ahead of predicted land loss. And in the United States, melting permafrost is causing chunks
of the Alaskan coastline to erode. In some ways, this is nothing new. Humanity has always adapted
to changing weather and moved to regions that best support
cultural lifestyles and livelihoods. However, scientists agree 
that this rise in extreme weather is a by-product of Earth’s 
rapidly changing climate. Global warming increases the frequency and
intensity of storms, flooding and drought, while also melting polar ice caps 
and raising sea levels. These factors are changing the environment
much faster than they have in the past. Even for communities with the resources 
to take action, the variable pace and nature of these
changes makes them difficult to adapt to. And the vulnerable populations most
impacted by climate change are often those least responsible. Many facing climate mobility live 
in farming and fishing communities in countries that generate dramatically 
fewer emissions than their larger counterparts. Bangladesh is one such country. The nation has a unique combination
of low-lying geography and heavily populated coastal regions. Most of these vulnerable coastal families,
like those in Mohammadpur, don’t want to abandon 
their homes and livelihoods. And for others, leaving Bangladesh
isn’t financially practical. So to stay with their communities, many have moved a few meters inland and built more resilient homes
on higher ground or elevated stilts. Others have tried to buy land on newly
emerging islands in the delta, while some have sent family members
to find work in nearby cities. A handful of individuals might even cross
international borders, if they have family, friends, or work 
connections on the other side. But many of the residents who’ve left
are eager to return home. Unfortunately, it's unclear when
weather extremes will die down, and the government has repeatedly delayed
projects to build concrete embankments that would prevent further erosion. In other parts of the world, people couldn’t move inland 
even if they wanted to. The low-lying Pacific Island nations 
of Kiribati and Tuvalu are only 811 square kilometers
and 26 square kilometers, respectively; so migration would mean moving 
to a different country altogether. Instead, their governments and citizens
have united in physically, legally, and politically 
fortifying their countries. Island residents are planting
coastal mangrove forests, and building up low-lying areas of land
with dredged sand to shield themselves against storms 
and rising sea levels. And the islands’ governments have
repeatedly lobbied on the global stage for countries with the highest emissions 
to reduce pollution and take responsibility 
for climate change. The challenges facing
each coastal community are unique, and the diversity of the people's
experiences can make climate mobility a difficult phenomenon 
to measure and define. But as new communities are endangered
by extreme weather, it’s more important than ever
to listen to those on the front lines of this crisis.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What actions are being taken by the governments and citizens of island nations Tuvalu and Kiribati on climate change:
Options: A. Planting mangroves, B. Building up low-lying areas, C. Lobbying to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the main reason for the frequent flooding in Mohammadpur? Options: A. Heavy rainfall, B. Intense cyclones, C. Erosion of the coastline, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 3: In what year did the Meghna River overtake the coastline by 2.5 kilometers, forcing many villagers to move inland or to nearby cities? Options: A. 2000, B. 2010, C. 2020, D. 2050 Correct Option: A

Sending family members to find work in nearby cities, C. Abandoning their homes and livelihoods, D. Moving to a different country Correct Option: C
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the main cause of the rise in extreme weather? Options: A. Human activity, B. Natural disasters, C. Global warming, D. Climate change Correct Option: D
Question 6: Which of the following countries is not responsible for a significant amount of greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. United States, B. China, C. Bangladesh, D. Bangladesh Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the name of the Pacific Island nation with a land area of 26 square kilometers? Options: A. Kiribati, B. Tuvalu, C. Fiji, D. Solomon Islands Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one way that the residents of Kiribati and Tuvalu are adapting to the rising sea levels? Options: A. Building concrete embankments, B. Planting coastal mangrove forests, C. Moving to a different country, D. Lobbying for countries with high emissions to reduce pollution Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main challenge facing coastal communities in terms of measuring and defining climate mobility? Options: A. The lack of data, B. The diversity of experiences, C. The complexity of the issue, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the importance of listening to those on the front lines of the climate crisis? Options: A. To understand the impact of climate change, B. To develop solutions to the problem, C. To raise awareness about the issue, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

A more accurate match would be a question that includes all the actions mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Mohammadpur has always had 
a unique relationship with the weather. Located at the mouth of the Bay of Bengal, this coastal village was built 
on top of the Meghna River delta. Deltas are a kind of landmass formed 
when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where that river meets 
a larger body of water. River deltas are incredibly fertile
ecosystems capable of supporting abundant agriculture
and marine life. However, their borders gradually change
as rivers bring more sediment in and storms wash sediment away. The residents of Mohammadpur are well
accustomed to managing the ebbs and flows of this ever-shifting
landscape. But lately, an abundance of intense
cyclones have caused frequent flooding that impedes farming and fishing. These floods also erode the coastline, allowing later storms to wipe
away land altogether. Since 2000, the Meghna River has overtaken
the coastline by 2.5 kilometers, forcing many villagers to move inland
or to nearby cities. Mohammadpur isn’t the only place 
where erratic weather is impacting people’s mobility. Repeated typhoons in the Philippines have 
displaced thousands from their homes. In Fiji, the government is already moving
many coastal villages inland to get ahead of predicted land loss. And in the United States, melting permafrost is causing chunks
of the Alaskan coastline to erode. In some ways, this is nothing new. Humanity has always adapted
to changing weather and moved to regions that best support
cultural lifestyles and livelihoods. However, scientists agree 
that this rise in extreme weather is a by-product of Earth’s 
rapidly changing climate. Global warming increases the frequency and
intensity of storms, flooding and drought, while also melting polar ice caps 
and raising sea levels. These factors are changing the environment
much faster than they have in the past. Even for communities with the resources 
to take action, the variable pace and nature of these
changes makes them difficult to adapt to. And the vulnerable populations most
impacted by climate change are often those least responsible. Many facing climate mobility live 
in farming and fishing communities in countries that generate dramatically 
fewer emissions than their larger counterparts. Bangladesh is one such country. The nation has a unique combination
of low-lying geography and heavily populated coastal regions. Most of these vulnerable coastal families,
like those in Mohammadpur, don’t want to abandon 
their homes and livelihoods. And for others, leaving Bangladesh
isn’t financially practical. So to stay with their communities, many have moved a few meters inland and built more resilient homes
on higher ground or elevated stilts. Others have tried to buy land on newly
emerging islands in the delta, while some have sent family members
to find work in nearby cities. A handful of individuals might even cross
international borders, if they have family, friends, or work 
connections on the other side. But many of the residents who’ve left
are eager to return home. Unfortunately, it's unclear when
weather extremes will die down, and the government has repeatedly delayed
projects to build concrete embankments that would prevent further erosion. In other parts of the world, people couldn’t move inland 
even if they wanted to. The low-lying Pacific Island nations 
of Kiribati and Tuvalu are only 811 square kilometers
and 26 square kilometers, respectively; so migration would mean moving 
to a different country altogether. Instead, their governments and citizens
have united in physically, legally, and politically 
fortifying their countries. Island residents are planting
coastal mangrove forests, and building up low-lying areas of land
with dredged sand to shield themselves against storms 
and rising sea levels. And the islands’ governments have
repeatedly lobbied on the global stage for countries with the highest emissions 
to reduce pollution and take responsibility 
for climate change. The challenges facing
each coastal community are unique, and the diversity of the people's
experiences can make climate mobility a difficult phenomenon 
to measure and define. But as new communities are endangered
by extreme weather, it’s more important than ever
to listen to those on the front lines of this crisis.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT true:
Options: A. Climate change is affecting the ways in which people in coastal areas live and work., B. Most people in Mohammadpur want to stay close to their current homes, C. Most people in Tuvalu want to move to a new country., D. Human mobility associated with climate change is difficult to define and measure. 
Correct Option: C
