Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water
extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand
for electricity, valves open, releasing the stored energy 
by letting water flow downhill to power 6 giant turbines that can 
generate 3 billion watts of power for 10 hours. We’re going to need more and more 
giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount 
of greenhouse gas: 14 billion tons per year. We’ll need to get that number 
down to net-zero. But many clean energy sources 
can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

Question: All of the following are examples of batteries, except:
Options: A. A crane linked to a tower , B. Melted salts, C. Floor rugs, D. Bacteria on paper activated by spit
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Since 1850, global temperatures have increased by an average of:
Options: A. 1 Degree Fahrenheit, B. 3 Degrees Celsius, C. 1 Degree Celsius, D. 10 Degree Fahrenheit
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did the two frogs find themselves after being kidnapped? Options: A. In a field, B. In a kitchen, C. In a forest, D. In a river Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the outcome when the chef slowly heated the water, and the frog was unaware of the temperature rise? Options: A. The frog jumped out of the window, B. The frog basked in the balmy water, C. The frog boiled to death, D. The frog was taken out of the pot Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary cause of the Earth's temperature rise since 1850? Options: A. Deforestation, B. Burning fossil fuels, C. Industrialization, D. Natural disasters Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the effect of adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere? Options: A. More heat escapes into space, B. Less heat escapes into space, C. No change in heat escape, D. Heat is absorbed by the atmosphere Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the predicted temperature rise by 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions continue at the current pace? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius, B. 2 degrees Celsius, C. 4 degrees Celsius, D. 5 degrees Celsius Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the identified threshold beyond which the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius, B. 1.5 degrees Celsius, C. 2 degrees Celsius, D. 3 degrees Celsius Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the term for getting greenhouse gas emissions down to zero as fast as possible? Options: A. Net zero, B. Zero emissions, C. Carbon neutral, D. Sustainable emissions Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why is it not possible to keep emitting greenhouse gases and sequester all the carbon through natural methods? Options: A. It's too expensive, B. It's not technologically feasible, C. It's not possible to keep up with emissions, D. It's not environmentally friendly Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect of global average temperatures increasing 1 degree Celsius? Options: A. All places will warm equally, B. Some places will warm more than others, C. No change in temperature, D. Temperature will decrease Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main solution to mitigate the damage caused by climate change? Options: A. Jumping out of the proverbial pot, B. Reaching over and turning down the heat, C. Using clean energy and fuels, D. Sequestering carbon through natural methods Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. However, the options and the question content do not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the average global temperature rise since 1850 and provides options that include the correct answer of 1 degree Celsius.

Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose the most similar one based on the content, I would say Question 9 is the closest, but with a significant difference in the question's intent and options.

If I had to provide an index, I would say Question 9 is the closest match, but with a note that it's not a perfect match.

Index: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following are greenhouse gases
Options: A. Methane and Oxygen, B. Nitrogen and Oxygen, C. Carbon Dioxide and Nitrogen, D. Methane and Carbon Dioxide
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did the two frogs find themselves after being kidnapped? Options: A. In a field, B. In a kitchen, C. In a forest, D. In a river Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the outcome when the chef slowly heated the water, and the frog was unaware of the temperature rise? Options: A. The frog jumped out of the window, B. The frog basked in the balmy water, C. The frog boiled to death, D. The frog was taken out of the pot Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary cause of the Earth's temperature rise since 1850? Options: A. Deforestation, B. Burning fossil fuels, C. Industrialization, D. Natural disasters Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the effect of adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere? Options: A. More heat escapes into space, B. Less heat escapes into space, C. No change in heat escape, D. Heat is absorbed by the atmosphere Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the predicted temperature rise by 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions continue at the current pace? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius, B. 2 degrees Celsius, C. 4 degrees Celsius, D. 5 degrees Celsius Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the identified threshold beyond which the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius, B. 1.5 degrees Celsius, C. 2 degrees Celsius, D. 3 degrees Celsius Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the term for getting greenhouse gas emissions down to zero as fast as possible? Options: A. Net zero, B. Zero emissions, C. Carbon neutral, D. Sustainable emissions Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why is it not possible to keep emitting greenhouse gases and sequester all the carbon through natural methods? Options: A. It's too expensive, B. It's not technologically feasible, C. It's not possible to keep up with emissions, D. It's not environmentally friendly Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the effect of global average temperatures increasing 1 degree Celsius? Options: A. All places will warm equally, B. Some places will warm more than others, C. No change in temperature, D. Temperature will decrease Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main solution to mitigate the damage caused by climate change? Options: A. Jumping out of the proverbial pot, B. Reaching over and turning down the heat, C. Using clean energy and fuels, D. Sequestering carbon through natural methods Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists predict global average temperatures will rise by 4 degrees from preindustrial level by ____ if our current greenhouse gas emissions persist.
Options: A. 2050, B. 2100, C. 2033, D. 2200
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5

in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1967, researchers from around the world gathered to answer 
a long-running scientific question— just how long is a second? It might seem obvious at first. A second is the tick of a clock, the swing of a pendulum, 
the time it takes to count to one. But how precise are those measurements? What is that length based on? And how can we scientifically define
this fundamental unit of time? For most of human history, 
ancient civilizations measured time with unique calendars that tracked the steady march
of the night sky. In fact, the second as we know it wasn’t
introduced until the late 1500’s, when the Gregorian calendar 
began to spread across the globe alongside British colonialism. The Gregorian calendar defined a day
as a single revolution of the Earth about its axis. Each day could be divided into 24 hours,
each hour into 60 minutes, and each minute into 60 seconds. However, when it was first defined, the second was more of a mathematical
idea than a useful unit of time. Measuring days and hours was sufficient
for most tasks in pastoral communities. It wasn’t until society became
interconnected through fast-moving railways that cities
needed to agree on exact timekeeping. By the 1950’s, numerous global systems
required every second to be perfectly accounted for,
with as much precision as possible. And what could be more precise
than the atomic scale? As early as 1955, researchers began
to develop atomic clocks, which relied on the unchanging laws
of physics to establish a new foundation
for timekeeping. An atom consists of negatively charged
electrons orbiting a positively charged nucleus
at a consistent frequency. The laws of quantum mechanics 
keep these electrons in place, but if you expose an atom 
to an electromagnetic field such as light or radio waves, you can slightly disturb an electron’s
orientation. And if you briefly tweak an electron
at just the right frequency, you can create a vibration 
that resembles a ticking pendulum. Unlike regular pendulums that quickly lose
energy, electrons can tick for centuries. To maintain consistency and make ticks 
easier to measure, researchers vaporize the atoms, converting them to a less interactive
and volatile state. But this process doesn’t slow down
the atom’s remarkably fast ticking. Some atoms can oscillate 
over nine billion times per second, giving atomic clocks an unparalleled
resolution for measuring time. And since every atom of a given
elemental isotope is identical, two researchers using the same element
and the same electromagnetic wave should produce perfectly
consistent clocks. But before timekeeping could
go fully atomic, countries had to decide which atom 
would work best. This was the discussion in 1967, at the Thirteenth General Conference 
of the International Committee for Weights and Measures. There are 118 elements
on the periodic table, each with their own unique properties. For this task, the researchers were
looking for several things. The element needed to have long-lived and high frequency electron oscillation
for precise, long-term timekeeping. To easily track this oscillation, it also needed to have a reliably
measurable quantum spin— meaning the orientation of the axis
about which the electron rotates— as well as a simple energy
level structure— meaning the active electrons are few
and their state is simple to identify. Finally, it needed to be easy to vaporize. The winning atom? Cesium-133. Cesium was already a popular
element for atomic clock research, and by 1968, some cesium clocks
were even commercially available. All that was left was to determine
how many ticks of a cesium atom were in a second. The conference used the most
precise astronomical measurement of a second available at the time— beginning with the number of days
in a year and dividing down. When compared to the atom’s ticking rate, the results formally defined one second as exactly 9,192,631,770 ticks
of a cesium-133 atom. Today, atomic clocks are used all over
the Earth— and beyond it. From radio signal transmitters 
to satellites for global positioning systems, these devices have been synchronized to help us maintain a globally
consistent time— with precision that’s second to none.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did ancient civilizations measure time?
Options: A. They used ocean tides, B. They used unique calendars that tracked the night sky, C. With the Gregorian calendar, D. With the movement of the sun
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary question researchers sought to answer in 1967? Options: A. How to measure the length of a day, B. How to define the second as a fundamental unit of time, C. How to develop atomic clocks, D. How to synchronize global timekeeping systems Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which calendar introduced the concept of a day being a single revolution of the Earth about its axis? Options: A. Julian calendar, B. Gregorian calendar, C. Mayan calendar, D. Egyptian calendar Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary characteristic of an atomic clock that makes it precise? Options: A. Its reliance on the laws of quantum mechanics, B. Its ability to measure time on the atomic scale, C. Its use of electromagnetic fields to disturb electron orientation, D. Its ability to tick for centuries Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the frequency of oscillation of some atoms that can be used in atomic clocks? Options: A. Over 100 billion times per second, B. Over 1 billion times per second, C. Over 9 billion times per second, D. Over 10 billion times per second Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which element was chosen as the best candidate for atomic clocks in 1967? Options: A. Hydrogen, B. Helium, C. Cesium-133, D. Oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main reason cesium-133 was chosen as the best candidate for atomic clocks? Options: A. Its high frequency electron oscillation, B. Its simple energy level structure, C. Its reliable quantum spin, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the definition of one second in terms of the number of ticks of a cesium-133 atom? Options: A. Exactly 9,192,631,670 ticks, B. Exactly 9,192,631,770 ticks, C. Exactly 9,192,631,870 ticks, D. Exactly 9,192,631,970 ticks Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary purpose of atomic clocks in modern times? Options: A. To measure the length of a day, B. To synchronize global timekeeping systems, C. To develop new atomic clock technology, D. To measure the frequency of oscillation of atoms Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the benefit of using atomic clocks in radio signal transmitters and satellites for global positioning systems? Options: A. They provide more accurate location information, B. They provide more accurate time information, C. They provide more accurate frequency information, D. They provide more accurate velocity information Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the result of synchronizing atomic clocks to help maintain a globally consistent time? Options: A. A reduction in the accuracy of timekeeping, B. An increase in the complexity of timekeeping, C. A decrease in the cost of timekeeping, D. A precision that's second to none Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1967, researchers from around the world gathered to answer 
a long-running scientific question— just how long is a second? It might seem obvious at first. A second is the tick of a clock, the swing of a pendulum, 
the time it takes to count to one. But how precise are those measurements? What is that length based on? And how can we scientifically define
this fundamental unit of time? For most of human history, 
ancient civilizations measured time with unique calendars that tracked the steady march
of the night sky. In fact, the second as we know it wasn’t
introduced until the late 1500’s, when the Gregorian calendar 
began to spread across the globe alongside British colonialism. The Gregorian calendar defined a day
as a single revolution of the Earth about its axis. Each day could be divided into 24 hours,
each hour into 60 minutes, and each minute into 60 seconds. However, when it was first defined, the second was more of a mathematical
idea than a useful unit of time. Measuring days and hours was sufficient
for most tasks in pastoral communities. It wasn’t until society became
interconnected through fast-moving railways that cities
needed to agree on exact timekeeping. By the 1950’s, numerous global systems
required every second to be perfectly accounted for,
with as much precision as possible. And what could be more precise
than the atomic scale? As early as 1955, researchers began
to develop atomic clocks, which relied on the unchanging laws
of physics to establish a new foundation
for timekeeping. An atom consists of negatively charged
electrons orbiting a positively charged nucleus
at a consistent frequency. The laws of quantum mechanics 
keep these electrons in place, but if you expose an atom 
to an electromagnetic field such as light or radio waves, you can slightly disturb an electron’s
orientation. And if you briefly tweak an electron
at just the right frequency, you can create a vibration 
that resembles a ticking pendulum. Unlike regular pendulums that quickly lose
energy, electrons can tick for centuries. To maintain consistency and make ticks 
easier to measure, researchers vaporize the atoms, converting them to a less interactive
and volatile state. But this process doesn’t slow down
the atom’s remarkably fast ticking. Some atoms can oscillate 
over nine billion times per second, giving atomic clocks an unparalleled
resolution for measuring time. And since every atom of a given
elemental isotope is identical, two researchers using the same element
and the same electromagnetic wave should produce perfectly
consistent clocks. But before timekeeping could
go fully atomic, countries had to decide which atom 
would work best. This was the discussion in 1967, at the Thirteenth General Conference 
of the International Committee for Weights and Measures. There are 118 elements
on the periodic table, each with their own unique properties. For this task, the researchers were
looking for several things. The element needed to have long-lived and high frequency electron oscillation
for precise, long-term timekeeping. To easily track this oscillation, it also needed to have a reliably
measurable quantum spin— meaning the orientation of the axis
about which the electron rotates— as well as a simple energy
level structure— meaning the active electrons are few
and their state is simple to identify. Finally, it needed to be easy to vaporize. The winning atom? Cesium-133. Cesium was already a popular
element for atomic clock research, and by 1968, some cesium clocks
were even commercially available. All that was left was to determine
how many ticks of a cesium atom were in a second. The conference used the most
precise astronomical measurement of a second available at the time— beginning with the number of days
in a year and dividing down. When compared to the atom’s ticking rate, the results formally defined one second as exactly 9,192,631,770 ticks
of a cesium-133 atom. Today, atomic clocks are used all over
the Earth— and beyond it. From radio signal transmitters 
to satellites for global positioning systems, these devices have been synchronized to help us maintain a globally
consistent time— with precision that’s second to none.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the second introduced?
Options: A. 426 BCE, B. Late 1500’s, C. In the 1800’s, D. 1708
Correct Option: B

According to the transcript, the Gregorian calendar defined a day as a single revolution of the Earth about its axis and introduced the second as a unit of time in the late 1500's.

the Earth— and beyond it. From radio signal transmitters 
to satellites for global positioning systems, these devices have been synchronized to help us maintain a globally
consistent time— with precision that’s second to none.

In 1967, researchers from around the world gathered to answer 
a long-running scientific question— just how long is a second? It might seem obvious at first. A second is the tick of a clock, the swing of a pendulum, 
the time it takes to count to one. But how precise are those measurements? What is that length based on? And how can we scientifically define

began to spread across the globe alongside British colonialism. The Gregorian calendar defined a day
as a single revolution of the Earth about its axis. Each day could be divided into 24 hours,
each hour into 60 minutes, and each minute into 60 seconds. However, when it was first defined, the second was more of a mathematical
idea than a useful unit of time. Measuring days and hours was sufficient
for most tasks in pastoral communities. It wasn’t until society became
interconnected through fast-moving railways that cities
needed to agree on exact timekeeping. By the 1950’s, numerous global systems
required every second to be perfectly accounted for,
with as much precision as possible. And what could be more precise
than the atomic scale? As early as 1955, researchers began
to develop atomic clocks, which relied on the unchanging laws
of physics to establish a new foundation
for timekeeping. An atom consists of negatively charged

to satellites for global positioning systems, these devices have been synchronized to help us maintain a globally
consistent time— with precision that’s second to none.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What qualities were researchers looking for to decide which element would work best for the atomic time?
Options: A. The element needed to have long-lived and high frequency electron oscillation, B. The element needed to have reliable and measurable quantum spin, C. The element has to be easy to vaporize, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary question researchers sought to answer in 1967? Options: A. How to measure the length of a day, B. How to define the second as a fundamental unit of time, C. How to develop atomic clocks, D. How to synchronize global timekeeping systems Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which calendar introduced the concept of a day being a single revolution of the Earth about its axis? Options: A. Julian calendar, B. Gregorian calendar, C. Mayan calendar, D. Egyptian calendar Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary characteristic of an atomic clock that makes it precise? Options: A. Its reliance on the laws of quantum mechanics, B. Its ability to measure time on the atomic scale, C. Its use of electromagnetic fields to disturb electron orientation, D. Its ability to tick for centuries Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the frequency of oscillation of some atoms that can be used in atomic clocks? Options: A. Over 100 billion times per second, B. Over 1 billion times per second, C. Over 9 billion times per second, D. Over 10 billion times per second Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which element was chosen as the best candidate for atomic clocks in 1967? Options: A. Hydrogen, B. Helium, C. Cesium-133, D. Oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main reason cesium-133 was chosen as the best candidate for atomic clocks? Options: A. Its high frequency electron oscillation, B. Its simple energy level structure, C. Its reliable quantum spin, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the definition of one second in terms of the number of ticks of a cesium-133 atom? Options: A. Exactly 9,192,631,670 ticks, B. Exactly 9,192,631,770 ticks, C. Exactly 9,192,631,870 ticks, D. Exactly 9,192,631,970 ticks Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary purpose of atomic clocks in modern times? Options: A. To measure the length of a day, B. To synchronize global timekeeping systems, C. To develop new atomic clock technology, D. To measure the frequency of oscillation of atoms Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the benefit of using atomic clocks in radio signal transmitters and satellites for global positioning systems? Options: A. They provide more accurate location information, B. They provide more accurate time information, C. They provide more accurate frequency information, D. They provide more accurate velocity information Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the result of synchronizing atomic clocks to help maintain a globally consistent time? Options: A. A reduction in the accuracy of timekeeping, B. An increase in the complexity of timekeeping, C. A decrease in the cost of timekeeping, D. A precision that's second to none Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As dawn breaks in the Babylonian city 
of Sippar, Beltani receives an urgent visit
from her brother. It’s 1762 B.C.E., 
during the reign of King Hammurabi. Beltani is a naditu —
a priestess and businesswoman, promised to the temple at birth. At puberty, she changed her name and gained her elevated naditu status 
in a ceremony where a priest examined the entrails 
of a sacrificed animal for omens. The naditu are an esteemed group drawn
from Babylonia’s most affluent families. Though the rules are different for naditu
in each city, in Sippar they are celibate
and never marry. They live inside the gagum, 
a walled area inside the temple complex, but are free to come and go,
and receive visitors. Beltani owns barley fields and a tavern. Her brother manages these businesses while she fulfils her duties
as a priestess. This morning, he makes 
a troubling accusation: her tavern keeper has been diluting
wine with water. If true, this means she’s been undermining
the business Beltani relies on to sustain her in old age. But the consequences would be even higher
for the tavern keeper: the punishment of diluting wine
is death by drowning. The temple court is meeting
this afternoon. Beltani has just a few short hours to find out whether there’s any truth 
to these allegations. But she can’t go to the tavern
to investigate. Taverns are off limits for priestesses,
even priestesses who own them. She could be burned to death for entering. So she sends for the tavern keeper 
to meet her at the temple of Shamash, the patron god of Sippar. The temple is a stepped pyramid 
called a ziggurat, in the heart of the city 
and visible from twenty miles away. It symbolically connects heaven and earth and is viewed as the literal home
of the god Shamash, who gave humanity the code of laws and is the judge 
of the Babylonian pantheon. Beltani leaves an offering of bread 
and sesame oil in a private room. She never enters the inner chamber 
of the temple where the god lives, a place so holy only high priestesses
and kings visit. Outside, worshippers play music 
and leave gifts, which are later collected and used to feed
temple workers, including the naditu. The tavern keeper is waiting
with grim news. She says Beltani’s brother has been
altering the weights used to measure payments
to cheat customers. When the tavern keeper confronted him, he falsely accused her
of watering down the wine. If true, Beltani’s brother 
is the dishonest one — and altering weights is another crime 
punishable by death. Beltani is running out of time
to get to the bottom of this. Though she can’t go to the tavern, she can check on the barley fields 
her brother manages to see if he’s been honest there. In the granary, she sees much more grain 
than he reported to her. He’s been cheating her out of her share. Like all naditu in Sippar, Beltani inherited the same portion 
of her father’s property as her brother. These were rare circumstances
for women in a time and place where property passed through men. Still, their families didn’t always honor
their rights. Although naditu traditionally
went into business with male relatives, the law stated they can choose
someone else if their brothers or uncles
weren’t up to the task. With the evidence she needs, 
she hurries to court. A judge presides over the temple court
along with two naditu — the overseer of the gagum and a scribe. Beltani asks to remove her brother 
as her business manager, citing the granary as evidence 
that he is mismanaging her properties. The judge grants her request. The scribe records the new contract 
in cuneiform into a wet clay tablet, and the matter is settled. She's protected her income 
and spared her brother’s life by withholding the true extent 
of his crimes. Perhaps it is time to adopt
a younger priestess: someone to take care of her in old age
and inherit her property, who might do a better job of helping
with her business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Beltani invests in several business ventures. Which two are discussed in the video (select all that apply)?
Options: A. Date palm fields, B. Barley fields, C. Tavern, D. Textile trading
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is Beltani, and what is her role in the Babylonian city of Sippar? Options: A. A king's advisor, B. A priestess and businesswoman, C. A temple worker, D. A tavern keeper Correct Option: B
Question 2: What ceremony did Beltani undergo at puberty to gain her elevated naditu status? Options: A. A marriage ceremony, B. A sacrifice ceremony, C. An examination of the entrails of a sacrificed animal for omens, D. A business meeting Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the punishment for diluting wine in the Babylonian city of Sippar? Options: A. Imprisonment, B. Fines, C. Death by drowning, D. Forced labor Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why is Beltani unable to investigate the allegations of her tavern keeper diluting wine? Options: A. Because she is a priestess and taverns are off-limits for priestesses, B. Because she is a businesswoman and doesn't have time, C. Because she is a king's advisor and doesn't have authority, D. Because she is a temple worker and doesn't have permission Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the purpose of the stepped pyramid called a ziggurat in the heart of the city of Sippar? Options: A. To house the god Shamash, B. B: To connect heaven and earth symbolically, C. To provide a meeting place for the temple court, D. To serve as a temple for the priestesses Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the role of the tavern keeper in the story? Options: A. To accuse Beltani's brother of cheating customers, B. To accuse Beltani of watering down the wine, C. To be the victim of Beltani's brother's cheating, D. To be the business partner of Beltani's brother Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the significance of the granary in the story? Options: A. It is a symbol of the temple's wealth, B. It is a place where the priestesses store their food, C. It is a place where Beltani's brother stores grain to cheat her, D. It is a place where the temple workers store their tools Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the outcome of the temple court's decision regarding Beltani's brother? Options: A. He is sentenced to death for cheating Beltani, B. He is removed as Beltani's business manager, C. He is acquitted of all charges, D. He is given a lighter sentence Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential outcome for Beltani's future business and property? Options: A. She will have to rely on her brother to manage her business, B. She will have to find a new business partner, C. She will be able to pass on her property to a younger priestess, D. She will have to sell her business and property Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the law stating that naditu can choose someone else to manage their business if their brothers or uncles are not up to the task? Options: A. It shows that the law favors the rights of men over women, B. It shows that the law favors the rights of women over men, C. It shows that the law allows for flexibility in business arrangements, D. It shows that the law is outdated and no longer relevant Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that partially matches the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Beltani's business ventures, specifically which two are discussed in the video. The generated MCQs do not directly ask about Beltani's business ventures, but some of them mention her business or properties.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 7: What is the significance of the granary in the story? Options: A. It is a symbol of the temple's wealth, B. It is a place where the priestesses store their food, C. It is a place where Beltani's brother stores grain to cheat her, D. It is a place where the temple workers store their tools Correct Option: C

Although this generated MCQ does not directly ask about Beltani's business ventures, it mentions the granary, which is related to her barley fields, one of the business ventures mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. However, it does not mention the tavern, which is the other business venture mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar generated MCQ, but it is not a perfect match.

**Transcript**:
As dawn breaks in the Babylonian city 
of Sippar, Beltani receives an urgent visit
from her brother. It’s 1762 B.C.E., 
during the reign of King Hammurabi. Beltani is a naditu —
a priestess and businesswoman, promised to the temple at birth. At puberty, she changed her name and gained her elevated naditu status 
in a ceremony where a priest examined the entrails 
of a sacrificed animal for omens. The naditu are an esteemed group drawn
from Babylonia’s most affluent families. Though the rules are different for naditu
in each city, in Sippar they are celibate
and never marry. They live inside the gagum, 
a walled area inside the temple complex, but are free to come and go,
and receive visitors. Beltani owns barley fields and a tavern. Her brother manages these businesses while she fulfils her duties
as a priestess. This morning, he makes 
a troubling accusation: her tavern keeper has been diluting
wine with water. If true, this means she’s been undermining
the business Beltani relies on to sustain her in old age. But the consequences would be even higher
for the tavern keeper: the punishment of diluting wine
is death by drowning. The temple court is meeting
this afternoon. Beltani has just a few short hours to find out whether there’s any truth 
to these allegations. But she can’t go to the tavern
to investigate. Taverns are off limits for priestesses,
even priestesses who own them. She could be burned to death for entering. So she sends for the tavern keeper 
to meet her at the temple of Shamash, the patron god of Sippar. The temple is a stepped pyramid 
called a ziggurat, in the heart of the city 
and visible from twenty miles away. It symbolically connects heaven and earth and is viewed as the literal home
of the god Shamash, who gave humanity the code of laws and is the judge 
of the Babylonian pantheon. Beltani leaves an offering of bread 
and sesame oil in a private room. She never enters the inner chamber 
of the temple where the god lives, a place so holy only high priestesses
and kings visit. Outside, worshippers play music 
and leave gifts, which are later collected and used to feed
temple workers, including the naditu. The tavern keeper is waiting
with grim news. She says Beltani’s brother has been
altering the weights used to measure payments
to cheat customers. When the tavern keeper confronted him, he falsely accused her
of watering down the wine. If true, Beltani’s brother 
is the dishonest one — and altering weights is another crime 
punishable by death. Beltani is running out of time
to get to the bottom of this. Though she can’t go to the tavern, she can check on the barley fields 
her brother manages to see if he’s been honest there. In the granary, she sees much more grain 
than he reported to her. He’s been cheating her out of her share. Like all naditu in Sippar, Beltani inherited the same portion 
of her father’s property as her brother. These were rare circumstances
for women in a time and place where property passed through men. Still, their families didn’t always honor

went into business with male relatives, the law stated they can choose
someone else if their brothers or uncles
weren’t up to the task. With the evidence she needs, 
she hurries to court. A judge presides over the temple court

as her business manager, citing the granary as evidence 
that he is mismanaging her properties. The judge grants her request. The scribe records the new contract 
in cuneiform into a wet clay tablet, and the matter is settled. She's protected her income 
and spared her brother’s life by withholding the true extent 
of his crimes. Perhaps it is time to adopt
a younger priestess: someone to take care of her in old age
and inherit her property, who might do a better job of helping
with her business.

Correct Option: D

As dawn breaks in the Babylonian city 
of Sippar, Beltani receives an urgent visit

and never marry. They live inside the gagum,

and receive visitors. Beltani owns barley fields and a tavern. Her brother manages these businesses while she fulfils her duties
as a priestess. This morning, he makes 
a troubling accusation: her tavern keeper has been diluting
wine with water. If true, this means she’s been undermining

is death by drowning. The temple court is meeting
this afternoon. Beltani has just a few short hours to find out whether there’s any truth

of the Babylonian pantheon. Beltani leaves an offering of bread 
and sesame oil in a private room. She never enters the inner chamber 
of the temple where the god lives, a place so holy only high priestesses
and kings visit. Outside, worshippers play music 
and leave gifts, which are later collected and used to feed

of her father’s property as her brother. These were rare circumstances

their rights. Although naditu traditionally
went into business with male relatives, the law stated they can choose
someone else if their brothers or uncles
weren’t up to the task. With the evidence she needs, 
she hurries to court. A judge presides over the temple court

as her business manager, citing the granary as evidence 
that he is mismanaging her properties. The judge grants her request. The scribe records the new contract 
in cuneiform into a wet clay tablet, and the matter is settled. She's protected her income

of his crimes. Perhaps it is time to adopt

and inherit her property, who might do a better job of helping
with her business.

and leave gifts, which are later collected and used to feed
temple workers, including the naditu. The tavern keeper is waiting
with grim news. She says Beltani’s brother has been
altering the weights used to measure payments
to cheat customers. When the tavern keeper confronted him, he falsely accused her
of watering down the wine. If true, Beltani’s brother 
is the dishonest one — and altering weights is another crime 
punishable by death. Beltani is running out of time
to get to the bottom of this. Though she can’t go to the tavern, she can check on the barley fields 
her brother manages to see if he’s been honest there. In the granary, she sees much more grain 
than he reported to her. He’s been cheating her out of her share. Like all naditu in Sippar, Beltani inherited the same portion 
of her father’s property as her brother. These were rare circumstances
for women in a time and place where property passed through men. Still, their families didn’t always honor
their rights. Although naditu traditionally
went into business with male relatives, the law stated they can choose
someone else if their brothers or uncles
weren’t up to the task. With the evidence she needs, 
she hurries to court. A judge presides over the temple court
along with two naditu — the overseer of the gagum and a scribe. Beltani asks to remove her brother 
as her business manager, citing the granary as evidence 
that he is mismanaging her properties. The judge grants her request. The scribe records the new contract 
in cuneiform into a wet clay tablet, and the matter is settled. She's protected her income 
and spared her brother’s life by withholding the true extent 
of his crimes. Perhaps it is time to adopt
a younger priestess: someone to take care of her in old age
and inherit her property, who might do a better job of helping
with her business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What makes Beltani decide to trust the tavern keeper rather than her brother?
Options: A. The tavern keeper is a trusted friend, B. Her uncle cautions her about trusting her brother, C. She visits the granary and learns her brother lied about the surplus, D. She has a premonition in a dream
Correct Option: C

Question 2: What ceremony did Beltani undergo at puberty to gain her elevated naditu status? Options: A. A marriage ceremony, B. A sacrifice ceremony, C. An examination of the entrails of a sacrificed animal for omens, D. A business meeting Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the punishment for diluting wine in the Babylonian city of Sippar? Options: A. Imprisonment, B. Fines, C. Death by drowning, D. Forced labor Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why is Beltani unable to investigate the allegations of her tavern keeper diluting wine? Options: A. Because she is a priestess and taverns are off-limits for priestesses, B. Because she is a businesswoman and doesn't have time, C. Because she is a king's advisor and doesn't have authority, D. Because she is a temple worker and doesn't have permission Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the purpose of the stepped pyramid called a ziggurat in the heart of the city of Sippar? Options: A. To house the god Shamash, B. B: To connect heaven and earth symbolically, C. Question 6: What is the role of the tavern keeper in the story? Options: A. To accuse Beltani's brother of cheating customers, B. To accuse Beltani of watering down the wine, C. To be the victim of Beltani's brother's cheating, D. To be the business partner of Beltani's brother Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the significance of the granary in the story? Options: A. It is a symbol of the temple's wealth, B. It is a place where the priestesses store their food, C. Question 9: What is the potential outcome for Beltani's future business and property? Options: A. She will have to rely on her brother to manage her business, B. She will have to find a new business partner, C. She will be able to pass on her property to a younger priestess, D. She will have to sell her business and property Correct Option: C

It shows that the law is outdated and no longer relevant Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question asks about the significance of the granary in the story, and the correct option (C) states that it is a place where Beltani's brother stores grain to cheat her. This matches the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, which asks what makes Beltani decide to trust the tavern keeper rather than her brother, with the correct option (C) stating that she visits the granary and learns her brother lied about the surplus.

Although the wording and focus of the two questions are slightly different, they both relate to the same event in the story (Beltani's discovery of her brother's dishonesty at the granary) and have similar implications for the plot. Therefore, Question 7 is the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As dawn breaks in the Babylonian city 
of Sippar, Beltani receives an urgent visit
from her brother. It’s 1762 B.C.E., 
during the reign of King Hammurabi. Beltani is a naditu —
a priestess and businesswoman, promised to the temple at birth. At puberty, she changed her name and gained her elevated naditu status 
in a ceremony where a priest examined the entrails 
of a sacrificed animal for omens. The naditu are an esteemed group drawn
from Babylonia’s most affluent families. Though the rules are different for naditu
in each city, in Sippar they are celibate
and never marry. They live inside the gagum, 
a walled area inside the temple complex, but are free to come and go,
and receive visitors. Beltani owns barley fields and a tavern. Her brother manages these businesses while she fulfils her duties
as a priestess. This morning, he makes 
a troubling accusation: her tavern keeper has been diluting
wine with water. If true, this means she’s been undermining
the business Beltani relies on to sustain her in old age. But the consequences would be even higher
for the tavern keeper: the punishment of diluting wine
is death by drowning. The temple court is meeting
this afternoon. Beltani has just a few short hours to find out whether there’s any truth 
to these allegations. But she can’t go to the tavern
to investigate. Taverns are off limits for priestesses,
even priestesses who own them. She could be burned to death for entering. So she sends for the tavern keeper 
to meet her at the temple of Shamash, the patron god of Sippar. The temple is a stepped pyramid 
called a ziggurat, in the heart of the city 
and visible from twenty miles away. It symbolically connects heaven and earth and is viewed as the literal home
of the god Shamash, who gave humanity the code of laws and is the judge 
of the Babylonian pantheon. Beltani leaves an offering of bread 
and sesame oil in a private room. She never enters the inner chamber 
of the temple where the god lives, a place so holy only high priestesses
and kings visit. Outside, worshippers play music 
and leave gifts, which are later collected and used to feed
temple workers, including the naditu. The tavern keeper is waiting
with grim news. She says Beltani’s brother has been
altering the weights used to measure payments
to cheat customers. When the tavern keeper confronted him, he falsely accused her
of watering down the wine. If true, Beltani’s brother 
is the dishonest one — and altering weights is another crime 
punishable by death. Beltani is running out of time
to get to the bottom of this. Though she can’t go to the tavern, she can check on the barley fields 
her brother manages to see if he’s been honest there. In the granary, she sees much more grain 
than he reported to her. He’s been cheating her out of her share. Like all naditu in Sippar, Beltani inherited the same portion 
of her father’s property as her brother. These were rare circumstances
for women in a time and place where property passed through men. Still, their families didn’t always honor
their rights. Although naditu traditionally
went into business with male relatives, the law stated they can choose
someone else if their brothers or uncles
weren’t up to the task. With the evidence she needs, 
she hurries to court. A judge presides over the temple court
along with two naditu — the overseer of the gagum and a scribe. Beltani asks to remove her brother 
as her business manager, citing the granary as evidence 
that he is mismanaging her properties. The judge grants her request. The scribe records the new contract 
in cuneiform into a wet clay tablet, and the matter is settled. She's protected her income 
and spared her brother’s life by withholding the true extent 
of his crimes. Perhaps it is time to adopt
a younger priestess: someone to take care of her in old age
and inherit her property, who might do a better job of helping
with her business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What material do Babylonian scribes use to record business contracts?
Options: A. Papyrus, B. Stone, C. Clay, D. Wood
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A mirror that shatters without warning. A trail of cracker crumbs 
strewn across the floor. Two tiny handprints that appear on a cake. Everyone at 124 Bluestone Road
knows their house is haunted— but there’s no mystery about 
the spirit tormenting them. This ghost is the product 
of an unspeakable trauma; the legacy of a barbaric history that hangs over much more 
than this lone homestead. So begins "Beloved," Toni Morrison’s 
Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about the suffering wrought by slavery
and the wounds that persist in its wake. Published in 1987, "Beloved" 
tells the story of Sethe, a woman who escaped enslavement. When the novel opens, Sethe 
has been living free for over a decade. Her family has largely dissolved—
Sethe’s mother-in-law died years earlier, and her two sons ran away 
from fear of the specter. Sethe’s daughter Denver remains 
in the house, but the pair live a half-life. Shunned by the wider community, the two have only each other 
and the ghost for company. Sethe is consumed by thoughts
of the spirit, whom she believes to be 
her eldest daughter. When a visitor from Sethe’s old life
returns and threatens the ghost away, it seems like the start of a new beginning
for her family. But what comes in the ghost’s place
may be even harder to bear. As with much of Morrison’s work, "Beloved" investigates the roles of trauma
and love in African-American history. Morrison writes about black identities
in a variety of contexts, but her characters are united 
by their desire to find love and be loved— even when it’s painful. Some of her novels explore when love
challenges social conventions, like the forbidden affection that grows
between the townsfolk of "Paradise" and their fugitive neighbors. Other works examine how we can be
blind to the love we already possess. In "Sula," one character realizes 
that it’s not her marriage, but rather, one of her friendships 
that embodies the great love of her life. Perhaps Morrison’s most famous
exploration of the difficulty of love takes place in "Beloved." Here, the author considers how 
the human spirit is diminished when you know the things and people
you love most will be taken away. Morrison shows that slavery 
is destructive to love in all forms, poisoning both enslaved people
and their enslavers. "Beloved" examines the dehumanizing
effects of the slave trade in numerous ways. Some are straightforward, 
such as referring to enslaved people as animals with monetary value. But others are more subtle. Sethe and Paul D.—
the visitor from her old plantation— are described as trying 
to “live an unlivable life.” Their coping mechanisms are different;
Sethe remains mired in her past, while Paul D. dissociates
himself completely. But in both cases, it’s clear each
character has been irreparably scarred. Morrison also blends 
perspectives and timelines, to convey how the trauma of slavery ripples across various characters
and time periods. As she delves into the psyche 
of townspeople, enslavers, and previously enslaved people, she exposes conflicting
viewpoints on reality. This tension shows the limitations
of our own perspectives, and the ways in which some characters are actively avoiding the reality
of their actions. But in other instances, the characters’
shifting memories align perfectly; capturing the collective trauma
that haunts the story. Though "Beloved" touches on dark subjects, the book is also filled 
with beautiful prose, highlighting its characters’ capacity
for love and vulnerability. In a stream-of-consciousness sequence
written from Sethe’s perspective, Morrison unspools memories of subjugation
alongside moments of tenderness; like a baby reaching for her mother’s
earrings, spring colors, and freshly painted stairs. Sethe’s mother-in-law had them
painted white, she recalls, “so you could see your way to the top… 
where lamplight didn’t reach." Throughout the book, Morrison asks
us to consider hope in the dark, and to question what freedom really means. She urges readers to ponder
the power we have over each other, and to use that power wisely. In this way, "Beloved" remains a testimony
to the destructiveness of hate, the redeeming power of love, and the responsibility we bear
to heed the voices of the past.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who does Sethe live with at 124 Bluestone Road?
Options: A. Her mother-in-law Baby Suggs, B. Her daughter Denver, C. Her husband Halle, D. Stamp Paid, who helped Sethe escape to freedom
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main theme of Toni Morrison's novel "Beloved"? Options: A. The struggle for independence in the American colonies, B. The suffering wrought by slavery and the wounds that persist in its wake, C. The importance of family and relationships in African-American history, D. The impact of the Civil War on American society Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who is the protagonist of the novel "Beloved"? Options: A. Paul D., B. Sethe, C. Denver, D. The ghost of Sethe's daughter Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the ghost in the novel? Options: A. It represents the spirit of freedom and independence, B. It symbolizes the trauma and pain caused by slavery, C. It serves as a reminder of the importance of family and relationships, D. It represents the power of love and redemption Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the effect of slavery on love, according to the novel "Beloved"? Options: A. It strengthens and deepens love, B. It destroys and poisons love, C. It has no impact on love, D. It creates new and unexpected forms of love Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does Toni Morrison portray the characters' experiences of trauma and slavery in the novel? Options: A. She presents a straightforward and objective account, B. She uses a stream-of-consciousness narrative to convey the characters' inner thoughts and feelings, C. She focuses on the physical and material aspects of slavery, D. She ignores the emotional and psychological impact of slavery Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the significance of the character Paul D. in the novel? Options: A. He represents the spirit of freedom and independence, B. He symbolizes the trauma and pain caused by slavery, C. He serves as a foil to Sethe, highlighting the different ways people cope with trauma, D. He represents the power of love and redemption Correct Option: C
Question 7: How does the novel "Beloved" explore the concept of hope in the face of darkness and trauma? Options: A. It presents a bleak and pessimistic view of the future, B. It offers a message of hope and resilience in the face of adversity, C. It ignores the importance of hope in the context of trauma, D. It presents a nuanced and complex exploration of hope and its limitations Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the significance of the character Sethe's mother-in-law in the novel? Options: A. She represents the spirit of freedom and independence, B. She symbolizes the trauma and pain caused by slavery, C. She serves as a reminder of the importance of family and relationships, D. She represents the power of love and redemption Correct Option: C
Question 9: How does the novel "Beloved" portray the relationship between the enslaved people and their enslavers? Options: A. It presents a straightforward and objective account of the power dynamics, B. It uses a stream-of-consciousness narrative to convey the characters' inner thoughts and feelings, C. It focuses on the physical and material aspects of slavery, D. It ignores the emotional and psychological impact of slavery Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall message of the novel "Beloved"? Options: A. The destructiveness of hate and the power of love, B. The importance of family and relationships in African-American history, C. The impact of the Civil War on American society, D. The struggle for independence in the American colonies Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the protagonist of the novel, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about who Sethe lives with at 124 Bluestone Road.

A more similar question would be one that asks about Sethe's relationships or living arrangements. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose:

He symbolizes the trauma and pain caused by slavery, C. He serves as a foil to Sethe, highlighting the different ways people cope with trauma, D. He represents the power of love and redemption Correct Option: C**

However, this question is still not a good match, as it asks about Paul D.'s significance, not Sethe's living arrangements.

After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Sethe's belief regarding the ghost's identity. While none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the ghost's identity, Question 2 mentions the protagonist (Sethe) and the ghost of Sethe's daughter as options.

Although not a perfect match, I would recommend Question 2 as the most similar generated MCQ, as it at least mentions the ghost and Sethe in the options.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Please note that this is not an exact match, and a more accurate generated MCQ would be needed to perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A mirror that shatters without warning. A trail of cracker crumbs 
strewn across the floor. Two tiny handprints that appear on a cake. Everyone at 124 Bluestone Road
knows their house is haunted— but there’s no mystery about 
the spirit tormenting them. This ghost is the product 
of an unspeakable trauma; the legacy of a barbaric history that hangs over much more 
than this lone homestead. So begins "Beloved," Toni Morrison’s 
Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about the suffering wrought by slavery
and the wounds that persist in its wake. Published in 1987, "Beloved" 
tells the story of Sethe, a woman who escaped enslavement. When the novel opens, Sethe 
has been living free for over a decade. Her family has largely dissolved—
Sethe’s mother-in-law died years earlier, and her two sons ran away 
from fear of the specter. Sethe’s daughter Denver remains 
in the house, but the pair live a half-life. Shunned by the wider community, the two have only each other 
and the ghost for company. Sethe is consumed by thoughts
of the spirit, whom she believes to be 
her eldest daughter. When a visitor from Sethe’s old life
returns and threatens the ghost away, it seems like the start of a new beginning
for her family. But what comes in the ghost’s place
may be even harder to bear. As with much of Morrison’s work, "Beloved" investigates the roles of trauma
and love in African-American history. Morrison writes about black identities
in a variety of contexts, but her characters are united 
by their desire to find love and be loved— even when it’s painful. Some of her novels explore when love
challenges social conventions, like the forbidden affection that grows
between the townsfolk of "Paradise" and their fugitive neighbors. Other works examine how we can be
blind to the love we already possess. In "Sula," one character realizes 
that it’s not her marriage, but rather, one of her friendships 
that embodies the great love of her life. Perhaps Morrison’s most famous
exploration of the difficulty of love takes place in "Beloved." Here, the author considers how 
the human spirit is diminished when you know the things and people
you love most will be taken away. Morrison shows that slavery 
is destructive to love in all forms, poisoning both enslaved people
and their enslavers. "Beloved" examines the dehumanizing
effects of the slave trade in numerous ways. Some are straightforward, 
such as referring to enslaved people as animals with monetary value. But others are more subtle. Sethe and Paul D.—
the visitor from her old plantation— are described as trying 
to “live an unlivable life.” Their coping mechanisms are different;
Sethe remains mired in her past, while Paul D. dissociates
himself completely. But in both cases, it’s clear each
character has been irreparably scarred. Morrison also blends 
perspectives and timelines, to convey how the trauma of slavery ripples across various characters
and time periods. As she delves into the psyche 
of townspeople, enslavers, and previously enslaved people, she exposes conflicting
viewpoints on reality. This tension shows the limitations
of our own perspectives, and the ways in which some characters are actively avoiding the reality
of their actions. But in other instances, the characters’
shifting memories align perfectly; capturing the collective trauma
that haunts the story. Though "Beloved" touches on dark subjects, the book is also filled 
with beautiful prose, highlighting its characters’ capacity
for love and vulnerability. In a stream-of-consciousness sequence
written from Sethe’s perspective, Morrison unspools memories of subjugation
alongside moments of tenderness; like a baby reaching for her mother’s
earrings, spring colors, and freshly painted stairs. Sethe’s mother-in-law had them
painted white, she recalls, “so you could see your way to the top… 
where lamplight didn’t reach." Throughout the book, Morrison asks
us to consider hope in the dark, and to question what freedom really means. She urges readers to ponder
the power we have over each other, and to use that power wisely. In this way, "Beloved" remains a testimony
to the destructiveness of hate, the redeeming power of love, and the responsibility we bear
to heed the voices of the past.

Options: A. Love and trauma in African-American history, B. The role of religion in the lives of enslaved people, C. The most important battles of the Civil War, D. Segregation and anti-miscegenation laws
Correct Option: A
